title: The Purification Festival at Lan-t'ing
text:
This meticulously painted handscroll illustrates thirty-nine scholars and their attendants clustered in various activities amongst powerful cedars and sweeping pines growing along a river course. The destination and purpose of these travelers is clarified by the pavilion built out over the water housing a scholar who pauses to watch the geese swimming below him. This is Wang Hsi-chih (321-379), the great calligrapher who, in 344, gathered his friends at Orchid Pavilion (Lan t'ing) about nine miles southeast of Shao-hsing in Chekiang province. A poetic account of the event was written by Wang Hsi-chih in a graceful script style said to have been influenced by his observation of the curvature of the geese's necks, and the text was destined to become the most famous and sought after text in Chinese history.

The pai-miao or monochromatic lineal style of painting seen here was a specialty of the Suchou artist Yu Ch'iu. His teacher in painting was the venerable classicist, Ch'iu Ying, whose works embody to near perfection the ideals of balance, emotional reserve, rationality, and high technical proficiency. These traits are readily evident in the works of Yu Ch'iu, considered one of Ch'iu Ying's best disciples and an important exponent of the classical tradition.
description: male figures and attendants in a lush landscape with water and buildings; text at front (partially on mount) and back
